prior_works.title: Gromov–Wasserstein distances and the metric approach to object matching
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the Gromov–Wasserstein discrepancy for comparing relational structures in a permutation-invariant way, the fundamental idea Any2Graph builds upon to compare predicted and target graphs.

prior_works.title: Sinkhorn Distances: Lightspeed Computation of Optimal Transport
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided entropic regularization and Sinkhorn iterations that make OT losses differentiable and scalable, enabling Any2Graph’s end-to-end training with an OT-based graph loss.

prior_works.title: Fused Gromov–Wasserstein Distance and Barycenter for Structured Objects
prior_works.authors: Titouan Vayer, Nicolas Courty, Rémi Flamary, Romain Tavenard
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proposed Fused GW to jointly align structural relations and node features, the direct precursor that Any2Graph extends via a partially-masked, task-ready FGW loss.

prior_works.title: Partial Gromov–Wasserstein with Applications
prior_works.authors: Laetitia Chapel, Mokhtar Z. Alaya, Gilles Gasso
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formalized partial GW to allow unmatched mass between structures, directly informing Any2Graph’s partially-masked design to handle graphs of different sizes.

prior_works.title: Unbalanced Optimal Transport: Dynamic and Kantorovich Formulations
prior_works.authors: Lénaïc Chizat, Gabriel Peyré, Bernhard Schmitzer, François-Xavier Vialard
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established unbalanced OT formulations and solvers for measures of unequal mass, supporting Any2Graph’s ability to compare any-sized graphs with principled mass relaxation.

prior_works.title: Gromov-Wasserstein Learning for Graph Matching and Node Embedding
prior_works.authors: Hongteng Xu, Dixin Luo, Lawrence Carin
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated GW as a differentiable loss within deep models for graph matching, evidencing the feasibility of end-to-end training with GW-type objectives that Any2Graph generalizes.

prior_works.title: End-to-End Object Detection with Transformers (DETR)
prior_works.authors: Nicolas Carion, Francisco Massa, Gabriel Synnaeve, Nicolas Usunier, Alexander Kirillov, Sergey Zagoruyko
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneered permutation-invariant set prediction via bipartite matching and ‘no-object’ slots, conceptually paralleling Any2Graph’s masking strategy for permutation-invariant graph supervision.

synthesis_narrative:
Any2Graph’s core innovation—a unified, end-to-end supervised graph prediction framework driven by a Partially-Masked Fused Gromov–Wasserstein (PM-FGW) loss—rests on merging foundational ideas from optimal transport (OT) and structured matching with practical, differentiable optimization. Mémoli’s formulation of Gromov–Wasserstein (GW) established a permutation-invariant way to compare relational structures, which is essential when supervising predicted graphs against targets without fixed node orderings. Cuturi’s entropic regularization and Sinkhorn iterations provided the computational and differentiable backbone that makes OT-based losses usable within deep learning at scale.
Vayer et al.’s Fused GW directly bridges structural relations and node features, a capability Any2Graph requires to supervise rich, attributed graphs; Any2Graph extends this by incorporating masking. Handling arbitrary graph sizes is enabled by partial and unbalanced OT advances: Chapel et al. formalized Partial GW to allow unmatched mass between structures, and Chizat et al. provided unbalanced OT formulations and solvers for unequal total mass—together motivating Any2Graph’s partially-masked design that gracefully treats extra/missing nodes. Prior deep learning work by Xu et al. validated GW as an end-to-end trainable loss for graph matching, supporting the feasibility of differentiating through GW-type objectives. Finally, the permutation-invariant supervision paradigm popularized by DETR’s bipartite matching and ‘no-object’ handling conceptually aligns with Any2Graph’s masking mechanism, but PM-FGW generalizes this to graphs by jointly considering structure and features through an OT lens. The synthesis yields a scalable, differentiable, permutation-invariant loss tailored to supervise full-graph predictions across domains.
